name: prunus-avium
wildlife-value: This is a larval host plant to Eastern Tiger Swallowtail (Papilio glaucus).  You may see three flights from February-November in the deep south and two flights from May-September in the north.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: Fleshy, yellow to red to purple-red, with a large pit (stone) and long stem.
flower-description: 1-few in a rounded cluster, 5-parted, 1-1.5 in.  Emerge with the leaves.
leaf-description: Toothed on the margin with 2 small red or green glands at the base of the blade.  Petiole has a groove.
bark-description: Very distinct horizontal lenticels.  Old wood may be grey with horizontal ridges.
poison-symptoms: The leaves, flowers, green fruits, ripe fruits and seeds contain cyanide compounds in detectable quantities, but the seeds and fruit stalks have the highest concentration of toxins. If a couple of pits (stones, which enclose the seeds) are accidentally swallowed, it will not cause poisoning, but care should be taken to remove pits before fruits are processed in a blender or any other machine that will crack open the pits. Symptoms include gasping, weakness, excitement, pupil dilation, spasms, convulsions, coma and respiratory failure.
